headline.main: Exercise Hormone May Fight Obesity and Diabetes

docs.abstract: A newly discovered hormone produced in response to exercise may be lessening susceptibility to obesity, diabetes and other health problems, a new study finds.
docs.snippet: A newly discovered hormone produced in response to exercise may be lessening susceptibility to obesity, diabetes and other health problems, a new study finds.

headline.main: Exercise Hormone May Fight Obesity and Diabetes

docs.abstract: A newly discovered hormone produced in response to exercise may be lessening susceptibility to obesity, diabetes and other health problems, a new study finds.
docs.lead_paragraph: A newly discovered hormone produced in response to exercise may be turning people's white fat brown, a groundbreaking new study suggests, and in the process lessening their susceptibility to obesity, diabetes and other health problems. The study, published on Wednesday in Nature and led by researchers at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Harvard Medical School, provides remarkable new insights into how exercise affects the body at a cellular level.
docs.snippet: A newly discovered hormone produced in response to exercise may be lessening susceptibility to obesity, diabetes and other health problems, a new study finds.

headline.main: In New Ads, Health Department Offers Super-Sized Warnings

docs.abstract: The city has begun its latest campaign against oversize portions of soda and fast food.
docs.lead_paragraph: The latest ads from New York City's health department warning against the dangers of sodas and fast food may not be as arresting as its previous public-service admonitions, but they are not too subtle.
docs.snippet: The city has begun its latest campaign against oversize portions of soda and fast food.

headline.seo: Stillbirth Causes Are Tallied, but Risks Remain a Challenge
headline.print_headline: New Clues Revealed In Studies Of Stillbirth
headline.main: New Clues Revealed in Studies of Stillbirth

docs.abstract: Two studies published in The Journal of the American Medical Association identify the most common causes of stillbirth, which occurs at a higher rate in the United States than in many other developed countries; studies find that known risk factors explain only a minority of stillbirth cases and conclude that more research is needed, particularly concerning disparities among races and ethnicities.
docs.lead_paragraph: Two studies in The Journal of the American Medical Association provide new clues, but many questions remain.
docs.snippet: Two studies in The Journal of the American Medical Association provide new clues, but many questions remain.

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations

headline.main: Economic Toll of Diabetes Begins Early

docs.abstract: Diabetes may be more than a hazard to health. A new study shows that young adults with the disease have lower lifetime earnings and fewer job prospects than their peers.
docs.snippet: Diabetes may be more than a hazard to health. A new study shows that young adults with the disease have lower lifetime earnings and fewer job prospects than their peers.
